title: R42395
content: A Retrospective of House Rules Changes Since the 110th Congress focuses on rules changes adopted by the House at the beginning of a new Congress, where the majority party organizes the House and writes its rules. Each new House adopts changes to the rules, a feature unique to the House compared to the Senate. The report is part of a series that examines rules changes in different Congresses. The 109th Congress saw extensive rules changes when Republicans took control of the House after 40 years of Democratic rule. The changes were grouped into five broad areas and further subdivided. The report also covers the Democratic critique of Republican management. The subsequent report focuses on the 110th and 111th Congresses under Democratic majority and the 112th to 115th Congresses under Republican majority. The report analyzes the critique by Democrats of Republican management of the House from the 104th through the 109th Congresses, and Democratic amendments proposed to Republican rules packages in the 112th through the 115th Congresses. Changes in rules resolutions from the 110th through the 115th Congresses are grouped into five broad subject areas and further explained. The report examines the critique by Democrats of Republican House management in various Congresses and the policy differences presented during rules debates. Changes in House rules were influenced by each party's critique when they took the majority in different Congresses. The report also organizes and explains changes made in rules resolutions from the 110th to the 115th Congresses. The report catalogs and briefly explains specific changes to House rules affecting committees, the House floor, budget legislation, House administration, and ethics standards in the 110th through the 115th Congresses. This report supplements the House Rules and Manual by Congress, containing provisions of House rules with notes on changes and decisions. Rules are arranged by number, with stable rule and clause numbers. The report does not cover all actions taken during each Congress for organizational, procedural, and administrative changes. The report catalogs permanent and temporary changes in the operation of the House, including rules changes, separate orders, and Speaker's policies. Changes are made through rules resolutions, orders, freestanding legislation, bills, resolutions, and report language. Legislative branch appropriations bills and budgetary legislation also contain organizational and procedural changes. Between the 110th and 115th Congresses, some committees' names were changed, impacting House rules and procedures. Special rules and unanimous consent agreements are adopted daily to adapt rules for consideration of measures. Additionally, changes in House rules are implemented through rules resolutions, orders, and legislation. In the 110th and 115th Congresses, committees' names were changed, impacting House rules. Democrats criticized Republicans' management of the House, focusing on ethics and legislative management. Democrats made incremental rules changes in the 109th Congress. In the 104th Congress, Democrats proposed new gift and copyright royalty income rules. In the 105th Congress, debate centered on the time limit for ethics committee deliberations on Speaker Gingrich. Democrats in the 106th Congress suggested adding clauses to the Code of Ethics regarding lobbying firms and political affiliation. In the 108th Congress, changes were made to ethics rules including allowing limited income from medical practice by Members who were doctors or dentists and permitting gifts. These changes were directed at addressing the K Street Project and were part of a Republican rules package. The Republican rules package for the 109th Congress made changes to the Standards of Official Conduct Committee procedures, criticized by Democrats as weakening ethical standards. Republicans defended the changes as ensuring Member rights and innocence presumption. Democrats objected to dropped rules allowing indicted Members in leadership roles and sought to remove a provision dismissing ethics complaints after 45 days. In response to changes in the rules package for the 109th Congress, Democrats sought to remove provisions that weakened ethical standards, including dismissing ethics complaints after 45 days. They also proposed banning gifts and travel from lobbyists as part of their "New Direction for America" initiative. The 109th Congress rules package included measures to strengthen ethical standards, such as banning gifts and travel from lobbyists, doubling the lobbying "cooling-off period," requiring disclosure of campaign contributions, and prohibiting Members from influencing lobbying firms' hiring decisions. Other provisions included disclosing outside employment negotiations, open conference committee meetings, voting on all agreements in a conference, disclosing earmarks, and posting conference reports electronically 24 hours before House consideration. Democratic Representatives introduced a House rules reform package in December 2005, known as H.Res. 659 in January 2006, with provisions related to ethics standards. These provisions included restrictions on accepting travel from lobbyists, requiring disclosure of campaign contributions, and prohibiting former Members from influencing lobbying firms' hiring decisions. The House rules reform package introduced by Democratic Representatives in December 2005 included provisions on ethics standards, such as restrictions on accepting travel from lobbyists, disclosure of campaign contributions, and prohibiting former Members from influencing lobbying firms' hiring decisions. Additionally, Democrats proposed rules requiring party ratios on committees and subcommittees to reflect the party ratio of the House in multiple Congresses. In the 104th, 107th, and 108th Congresses, Democrats proposed changes to rules resolutions affecting legislation with budgetary impact. Proposals included individual votes on Budget Act waivers, removing provisions on tax legislation estimates, appropriations bill content restrictions, and strengthening the majority leader's authority. In the 106th Congress, a pay-as-you-go rule was suggested for revenue and direct spending. In the 108th Congress, Democrats proposed amendments to rules resolutions seeking to eliminate procedural changes included in the resolutions. Their amendments aimed to strike provisions allowing oversight reports to be considered as read, requiring disclosure of federal contracts or grants by nongovernmental witnesses, adopting extended questioning time for hearings, and reducing the time for committee availability from three days to two. In the 106th and 108th Congress, Democrats proposed amendments to rules resolutions, aiming to reformulate legislation drafting and strike changes to House rules introduced by Republicans. The amendments included granting voting rights to the Delegate from the District of Columbia, making changes to existing law more discernible, and eliminating procedural changes such as extended questioning time for hearings and reducing committee availability time. The motion to commit in the 109th Congress addressed transparency issues in the legislative process, including honoring House rules on conference reports, reducing waivers in special rules, allowing more amendments, and granting more minority-party amendments under structured rules. In the 109th Congress, the House addressed legislative continuity in catastrophic circumstances following the 9/11 attacks and anthrax scares. A rules resolution included procedures for establishing a provisional quorum. A Democratic Member raised a constitutional point of order against the resolution, objecting to the provisional quorum rules as a violation of the Constitution. The House decided to proceed with the resolution. In the 109th Congress, Democrats criticized Republican legislative management and proposed changes. Nancy Pelosi announced "New House Principles" and "New Direction for America" with proposals for House management, including regular consultations between party leaders and a family-friendly schedule for legislative work. In the 109th Congress, Democrats pushed for "regular order" and "transparency" in legislative management, proposing changes to House rules for bill development and floor procedures. They emphasized the need for full hearings, open markups, and sufficient time for members to review bills before consideration. House rules for bill development and floor procedures emphasize open, fair debate with full amendment process. Members must have 24 hours to review bill text before floor consideration. Floor votes should be completed within 15 minutes, with no manipulation of outcomes. House-Senate conference committees should hold regular meetings and inform all conferees in a timely manner. "The Suspension Calendar should be limited to non-controversial legislation, with minority-authored bills scheduled based on party ratio. 'Pay As You Go' budgeting is a priority, with a focus on auditing federal spending for accountability. Recommendations for improving deliberative democracy have been proposed to ensure timely movement of the majority's agenda in the House." The "Broken Promises" report criticized special rules used in the House, recommending opening up the process for more debate and amendments. The report from the Rules Committee recommended allowing more serious amendments and bills to be debated under open rules, reducing the use of closed rules, and limiting late-night or early-morning 'emergencies'. The House Rules Committee should limit emergency meetings and prioritize regular order. Members should have three days to read conference reports. Representative Slaughter and other Democrats introduced a resolution for transparency and accountability in House rules. The House Rules Committee is implementing new rules to ensure transparency and accountability. These rules include requiring a three-day layover for conference reports, a roll-call vote on final agreement, and publication of voting records. Additionally, there will be changes to the layover rule for House special rules and publication of Members' voting records in the Congressional Record. The House Rules Committee is implementing new rules for transparency and accountability, including a three-day layover for conference reports, a roll-call vote on final agreement, and publication of voting records. Democratic Representatives introduced a House rules reform package, H.Res. 659, in January 2006, with provisions such as limiting roll-call votes to 20 minutes and allowing committee chairs to offer amendments. The House Rules Committee is implementing new rules for transparency and accountability, including a three-day layover for conference reports, a roll-call vote on final agreement, and publication of voting records. Additionally, the rules include provisions such as allowing the chair or ranking minority member of a committee to offer the committee-reported version of legislation as a preferential amendment and requiring printed copies of measures to be available 24 hours before consideration. The House Rules Committee is implementing new rules for transparency and accountability, including a three-day layover for conference reports, a roll-call vote on final agreement, and publication of voting records. Additionally, the rules include provisions such as extending Budget Act points of order to unreported legislation, disallowing bills with revenue provisions until identified by the Joint Committee on Taxation, and prohibiting adjournment sine die without a quorum call or recorded vote on at least 4 weekdays during 20 weeks of the session. Congressional procedures and practices were also addressed in the 2008 presidential campaign by Senator Barack Obama. Candidate Obama addressed reform issues, emphasizing transparency in Congress by making meetings where laws are written more open to the public. He promised that the public would have five days to review bills online before he signed them, and that corporate tax breaks and pork-barrel projects would be disclosed online. In the 110th Congress, Republicans attempted to change the special rule regarding congressional earmarks, following Senator John McCain's push for their elimination. Democratic control of the House in the early 21st century saw patterns of management that Republicans criticized and eventually addressed when they gained the majority in the 112th Congress. In the 111th Congress, Republicans proposed amendments to the rules resolution (H.Res. 6) to protect changes made during their majority, including prohibitions on special rules waiving automatic yeas and nays on certain measures and requiring a three-fifths vote on federal income tax rate increases. Republicans sought to preserve changes made during their majority by offering a motion to retain term limits on committee chairs and strike changes to the House rule concerning the motion to recommit. They criticized the limited opportunities for Member input and the lack of committee consideration for bills brought to the floor. The Rules Committee's Democratic majority faced criticism from Republicans for limiting amendments, using closed rules, and bypassing regular legislative processes to push through legislation. Republicans accused the Democrats of rewriting major legislation, excluding opposing viewpoints, and prioritizing partisan concerns. Additional criticism arose when Democrats moved to end open amendment processes for general appropriation bills in 2009. Republican criticism of Democrats' legislative management of the House focused on lack of transparency, last-minute proposals, and a desire for more floor debate and amendments. Republican leaders, including John A. Boehner, proposed a return to regular order in the legislative process. Republican leaders, including John A. Boehner, proposed changes to allow more floor debate and amendments, make committee-reported legislation the focus for debate, and ensure transparency in the legislative process. Boehner criticized the lack of legislative work in committees, stating that much of it has been taken over by leadership. Republican Whip Eric Cantor emphasized the importance of committee work in shaping the legislative agenda. Republican Whip Eric Cantor and Republican Leader Boehner emphasized the importance of committee work and transparency in legislative proceedings. Cantor highlighted the need for protected time for committees to conduct business, while Boehner discussed transparency rules such as giving at least three days' notice on all bills. The 2010 elections led to a change in House majority in the 112th Congress. Democrats proposed an amendment to the Republican rules package, aiming to overturn provisions exempting certain tax laws from the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act. This amendment was blocked, with concerns raised about increasing deficits and national debt through special interest tax breaks. The proposal before us eliminates the limitation on adding to the deficit by creating special interest tax breaks. Unlike previous Congresses, Democrats responded to Republican critiques in the 110th and 111th Congresses and proposed rule changes in the 112th Congress. In response to the Republican rules package in the 113th Congress, Democrats proposed amendments related to different policy stances. Democratic floor manager Louise Slaughter urged defeating the previous question motion to allow for an amendment on a joint resolution overturning the Citizens United Supreme Court decision. During the 114th and 115th Congresses, Democrats criticized the House rules for limiting their voting rights and the consideration of their amendments. They argued for more open debate and the inclusion of a wider range of public policy matters. Louise Slaughter called for a return to regular order and more diverse ideas in the House. The House rules resolution included a change allowing fines for breaching decorum with electronic devices, a response to Democrats' sit-in for anti-gun violence legislation. Following the Orlando nightclub massacre, Democratic Members opposed a House rule change that allowed punishment without due process, limited debate rights, and imposed a "gag rule." Representative John Lewis motioned to remove the change, but it was rejected. Another controversial change involved a standing order affecting budgetary legislation. The 115th Congress rules resolution included a standing order exemption that would impact legislation related to healthcare reform. Democrats criticized the exemption, arguing it could lead to a significant impact on the federal deficit, loss of health coverage, increased premiums, harm to Medicare recipients, and affect Medicare's solvency. Ranking Member Slaughter planned to offer an amendment to the rules resolution to address these concerns. The 115th Congress rules resolution included a standing order exemption that would impact healthcare reform legislation. Representative Slaughter planned to offer an amendment to prohibit bills affecting health benefits or taxes for the wealthy. The House ordered the previous question, preventing the offering of the amendment. Additionally, the resolution reintroduced the Holman Rule, allowing legislation on certain budgetary matters. The Holman Rule, previously deleted in 1983, was reintroduced in the 115th Congress rules resolution. Democrats raised concerns about the rule allowing the majority party to make budget cuts to federal employees. Delegate Eleanor Holmes Norton motioned to refer the resolution to a select committee to study voting rights for Delegates in the Committee of the Whole, but the motion was tabled. The section discusses changes made to the committee system in various Congresses, including structure, organization, procedure, staff, and funding. The 110th and 111th Congresses were organized by Democrats, while the 112th to 115th Congresses were organized by Republicans. In the 112th Congress, H.Res. 5 established the Intelligence Committee with a maximum of 20 members, with no more than 12 from the same party. In the 114th Congress, the committee size was increased to a maximum of 22 members, with no more than 13 from the same party. In the 111th Congress, the chair term limit was removed from House rules, and a Member could serve a second consecutive term as chair or ranking minority member of the Budget Committee. In the 112th Congress, the standing committee chair term limit was restored to not more than three consecutive Congresses. In the 110th Congress, a Select Committee on Energy Independence and Global Warming was created to investigate and make recommendations on reducing US dependence on foreign energy sources and addressing climate change. The committee was continued in the 111th Congress under H.Res. 5. The Lantos commission gained authority to collaborate with other relevant committees and use House resources through the Committee on Foreign Affairs. In the 114th and 115th Congresses, both parties focused on opening up decision-making to more voices. Members in the Democratic Caucus are organizing under the "progressive" banner, while Republicans are organizing under the "very conservative" banner. The congressional environment is influenced by various factors besides party control and the use of rules. Speaker Thomas Bracken Reed played a significant role in shaping the modern House, but the power dynamics changed with strong Speakers like Joseph Cannon. The Corrections Calendar, created in 1995, was terminated in the rules package for the 109th Congress. The consideration of legislation under suspension of the rules has become a more frequent procedure in the House, with motions to suspend the rules now being allowed on multiple days of House sessions. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974's requirement for two budget resolutions each year was found to be impractical and time-consuming, leading to its abandonment. The House rules are crucial for governance and are meant to be utilized by all Members, regardless of party affiliation.
